ai_comments.typography: Readable, modern sans with clear hierarchy, but largely default. Evidence: 1) Headline casing drifts — “Stunning Designs” (Title Case) vs “Thoughtful experiences” (sentence case) and later “Got a Project? Let’s talk.” with mixed capitalization; 2) Comfortable body measure and leading in hero (~60–70ch, ~1.4–1.6 leading); 3) Link pattern repeats (“Case Study →”, “Contact Us →”) with consistent arrow treatment; 4) Heavy display weight used repeatedly, creating blocky, same‑voice headings. Limitation: generic Inter‑like system with limited typographic voice and inconsistent casing. Red‑flag cap applied: template_scent_high limits Typography to 3.
ai_comments.layout_composition: Structure follows a standard landing‑page stack (centered hero → logo band → testimonials → project tiles → CTA → contact) with adequate spacing, but image handling and rhythm reduce polish. Evidence: 1) Project tiles use mixed aspect ratios and heights (text card next to an iPad mock; large green panel with a laptop) causing rhythm flicker; 2) Reliance on generic device frames (laptop/tablet/multiple phones) with tiny, unreadable UI; 3) The large green block behind the laptop disrupts vertical/value rhythm and feels disconnected from the grid; 4) Case‑study links float at different positions (e.g., top‑right on green tile) rather than a unified caption system. Limitation: lacks a cohesive POV and precise grid discipline. Red flags: sloppy_images (unreadable screenshots, mixed device frames, inconsistent tile sizes) → cap Layout at 2; template_scent_high (hero/logo band/testimonial modules) noted.
ai_comments.color: Base neutrals are pleasant (soft grey sections, dark navy text), but accent strategy is noisy. Evidence: 1) Competing accents — bright teal/green panel, cobalt‑blue links, and black pill CTAs; 2) The saturated green case‑study panel spikes value and overpowers nearby content; 3) Device screenshots introduce many additional hues without unifying mats/borders, increasing visual noise; 4) Project card backgrounds vary (green block, pale gradient, white), leading to value flicker across the grid. Limitation: needs a tighter accent system and unified mats to harmonize diverse imagery.

human_comments.typography:
This is an example of minimalist typography done poorly. Right off the bat, they don't consistently capitalize their sentences. They do it in some places but not others. 

They use emojis instead of bullet points which creates noise and adds a weird indent on the left. Emojis are not always bad, but they were using them pretty badly here. 

There's missing spacing between the bolded three lines and the stuff underneath it. It needs a little bit more separation. 

Then there's too much spacing between the case study text, so there's like a title and then there's a lot of space and then there's a label and then there's a lot of space again. But because the label is so small that it makes the spacing look even bigger, so that I would have probably put the label on top of the header text in the case study sections. 

They also use a completely different model space font for the button for no apparent reason. And then the button outline also doesn't match the stroke width of the text inside the button or frankly anything else on the page.
human_comments.layout_composition:
The layout is another one of those examples of just different for every section.
- The navbar is super wide
- It narrows down into the hero section (which is fine)
- It broadens a little wider again in the body where there's like case studies
I think that the hero and the case study section are technically the same width, but because the text on the hero doesn't run all the way to the right, it feels like it's not the same width. This creates this very awkward and inconsistent right rag.
human_comments.color:
There is sort of like an attempt here at doing sort of like an electric blue driven theme here, but because the case studies are also that backgrounds are sort of completely different colors and then they are very loud.

We're seeing gradients, we're seeing orange, we're seeing very dark blacks. It just takes away from the overall power of the monochrome plus electric blue color palettes.

ai_comments.typography: Readable, organized type with a clear hierarchy but not notably bespoke. Observations: 1) Project titles are set in a heavier weight with consistent Title Case, paired with small all‑caps meta (e.g., WEB/MOBILE) that repeats across items. 2) Body measures are comfortable (roughly 55–75ch) with stable leading; hero paragraph is left‑aligned and easy to scan. 3) Links use a bright cobalt blue consistently throughout. Limitations: the link styling feels defaultish (no visible custom underline/hover); casing mixes all‑lowercase in the hero/nav with Title Case headings, which weakens system cohesion; decorative emoji in hero/footer adds a casual tone that slightly reduces polish.
ai_comments.layout_composition: Structure is disciplined and repeats well across sections. Observations: 1) Case‑study rows use a consistent pattern (image left, text right) with matching aspect‑ratio thumbnails and uniform corner radii; gutters and image/text offsets look even. 2) The 'Additional Work' section maintains two equal columns with regular vertical rhythm; captions and VIEW CTAs align to the same grid. 3) Section labels ('CASE STUDIES', 'ADDITIONAL WORK') provide clear section breaks without width drift—containers feel consistent from hero through grid. Limitation: the very bold full‑width blue footer breaks the otherwise calm rhythm, and some tile heights in the two‑column area differ slightly, introducing minor vertical rhythm flicker.
ai_comments.color: Palette is serviceable with a single strong accent and calm neutrals. Observations: 1) Bright cobalt is used consistently for links and as the dominant footer color. 2) Thumbnail mats employ soft pastels (light blue, peach) plus a dark navy, generally controlled in value so text remains primary. 3) Neutral shell (white background, dark text, grey meta) supports readability. Limitation: the accent blue is very saturated and the solid blue footer creates a sharp value jump; mixed mat hues across tiles aren’t fully harmonized, causing mild color flicker.

ai_comments.typography: Readable, minimal sans system with clear hierarchy (oversized section titles, small meta above grids). Section headings are very large and consistent in weight, but casing varies across similar elements (e.g., 'Column', 'Webflow Brand', 'Ecom Site', 'Archive & Scraps', 'Webflow Dot Com'), weakening cohesion. The long heading 'Webflow Dot Com' wraps awkwardly into two lines, splitting 'Dot' and 'Com'. Link treatment and states are not evident, and body text is sparse, so rhythm/measure quality can’t be fully verified. Overall competent but generic voice with minor inconsistencies.
ai_comments.layout_composition: Strong, repeatable structure: each section uses a left title column, a thin horizontal rule, then a disciplined grid of uniformly sized square thumbnails with even gutters. Container width appears consistent across the long page; tile mats/crops look uniform and aligned, producing a steady scan. Small control badges ('M/L') and metadata blocks are aligned to the grid, showing attention to systemization. Limitations: the oversized headings occasionally create visual imbalance and a forced wrap ('Webflow Dot Com'); the hero sticky‑note vignette feels stylistically separate and slightly heavy in value; a few last rows end ragged due to uneven tile counts.
ai_comments.color: Neutral shell (white background, black text) lets artwork carry color, avoiding clashes. However, the grids mix very dark tiles with neon gradients and light tiles, causing value flicker within rows. The orange sticky note in the hero is a strong, isolated accent that spikes contrast compared with the rest of the page. No visible, consistent accent system for links or UI states. Overall serviceable harmony but not finely unified.

human_comments.typography: They used a pretty interesting serif here that I think is a sign that they have thought about this. The body also uses a relatively interesting looking model. But the problem is that the way that they use it is kind of bad. For example, a lot of the details around their bulleted list which is too indented, right? There's too much space on the left of their bullets. This subtracts points. The fact that they use a model only for their body is not great. Generally, you don't want to use a model for body text. It makes it a little hard to read. There's also a little bit of overuse of all caps and random tracking. If you look at the work writing dribble about navigation, they have just increased the letter spacing for no really good reason. Similarly, in the navbar, their name is a little too big in contrast to the rest of the navbar and competes with their main title.
human_comments.layout_composition:
The layout suffers from the typical sort of every section has a different width problem, but no intentionality. They also randomly shift from center-aligned to left-aligned.

So, if you look at the nav bar, it's kinda full-width. The header is quite narrow, and then the body is wide again. The "See my work" CTA is also super narrow, so it's kind of a little ragged and random.
human_comments.color: They chose a pretty interesting pair of colors for the green and the yellow. I think it's actually quite good because of their complementarity

ai_comments.typography: Distinct serif display for the hero paired with a clean sans for body/nav creates a clear hierarchy. Upper‑nav and section labels use spaced all‑caps consistently; hero title has tight but non‑colliding leading and balanced word breaks. Link styling is customized (teal color with underlines) and repeats across lists. Body copy in the three columns has comfortable leading and tidy bullets/rags. Limitation: the body text size is on the small side for desktop, and the centered intro paragraph feels slightly detached from the column system.
ai_comments.layout_composition: A disciplined three‑column grid under the hero with equal square illustration tiles, matched mats, and even gutters. Section labels, paragraphs, and bullet lists align cleanly under each tile, maintaining vertical rhythm. The top bar and hero establish a straightforward scan path. Limitations: only a single view is visible, and the centered outline CTA ('See my work') floats without anchoring to the three‑column grid, creating a minor break in structure; the centered intro block above the columns introduces a small alignment shift.
ai_comments.color: Cohesive palette: a single teal accent used for nameplate, links, nav, and button; off‑black text on off‑white background; beige illustration mats unify the three tiles and control value. Color roles are clear and consistent with no clashing elements, and value contrast remains calm across the page. Limitation: the teal accent reads slightly hot against the otherwise muted neutrals, and state colors (hover/visited) aren’t demonstrated.

ai_comments.typography: Readable serif body with comfortable ~55–65ch measure and generous 1.4–1.6 leading. Links appear in a bright defaultish blue with a standard underline weight/offset, suggesting little customization. Bullet points are typed as "•" characters, creating irregular indents and line-height wobble. Mixed pairing (serif body vs sans on buttons/nav) without clearly defined roles. Button copy like "Let's go ( password )" uses spaced parentheses and inconsistent casing, reducing polish. Limitation: no visible state system (hover/visited) and little evidence across multiple pages.
ai_comments.layout_composition: Simple two-column structure with ample whitespace and consistent horizontal dividers between sections. Headshot circle floats on the right and doesn’t anchor to the grid top/baseline, leaving a pocket of dead space. Right-side callout cards feel narrow and sit slightly detached from the left text block rhythm; vertical alignment between paragraph bottoms and card tops is not tuned. Bottom "Let’s connect" switches to centered social icons, breaking the left/right grid logic. Small logos inside the education block interrupt the text flow. Limitation: only one page view—no demonstration of responsiveness or longer grids.
ai_comments.color: Single accent family in blue is used consistently across links, CTAs, and callout cards. However, multiple blue values (light blue card, bright azure link, dark navy button) read as uncoordinated rather than a controlled scale. Neutrals appear as pure white background with near‑black/black text—serviceable but not tuned. Full‑color school/mascot marks introduce extra hues that add noise against the otherwise minimal palette. Limitation: no clear state color logic shown for interactions.

common_ai_blindspots: Template detection - AI misses obvious template usage
Sloppy execution - AI sees 'clean' where humans see 'careless'
